p: The emergence of resistance among Enterobacteriaceae as the most common human bacterial pathogen to a wide range of antibiotics, a great deal of burden is being forced on patients and healthcare systems [ 1]. The Enterobacteriaceae of pathogens accounts for 80% of Gram-negative bacterial isolates that cause a variety of human diseases, including urinary tract infections (UTIs). Escherichia coli is the most common cause of UTI, accounting for 85% and 50% of community-acquired and hospital-acquired UTIs, respectively [ 2]. E. coli bloodstream infection sources (BSIs) were found to have a urinary source in 34% of cases [ 3].
